summary_points: 1. Kimberly-Clark Corporation voluntarily delisted its common stock from the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) on May 29, 2025, and transferred the listing to Nasdaq, where it will continue trading under the symbol "KMB" starting May 30, 2025.
2.  The company amended its By-Laws on May 19, 2025, to remove certain NYSE-specific details regarding committees,  which are now addressed in committee charters.
3. The company's SEC filing identifies risks associated with the stock listing transfer, including potential delays, market disruptions, and negative impacts on its business operations.

1. Wabtec US Rail, Inc. became an additional guarantor of Westinghouse Air Brake Technologies Corporation's outstanding US Notes, as of May 19, 2025, due to its existing guarantee of a credit agreement with the company.

2.  For the three months ended March 31, 2025, the combined Parent Company and Guarantor Subsidiaries reported $1,532 million in net sales and $33 million in net income;  while for the year ended December 31, 2024,  net sales were $5,949 million and net income was a loss of $104 million.

3. The filing includes guarantor summarized financial information (Exhibit 99.1) reflecting the addition of Wabtec US Rail, Inc., showing a significant reduction in combined net income from the fiscal year end to the subsequent quarter.

1. Interstate Power & Light Company (IPL), a subsidiary of Alliant Energy Corporation, completed a public offering of $600 million aggregate principal amount of its 5.600% Senior Debentures due 2035 on May 19, 2025.

2. IPL intends to use the net proceeds from this offering to retire existing debt, reduce outstanding capital under its receivables program, reduce commercial paper, and for general corporate purposes.
3. Legal opinions from Perkins Coie LLP and Simmons Perrine Moyer Bergman PLC, dated May 19, 2025, confirm the legality of the debentures under relevant laws.
1. Steven D’Ambrosia, Altria's Vice President and Controller, retired on July 31, 2025, and Katie F. Patterson was appointed as his replacement, effective the same date.

2. At Altria's 2025 Annual Meeting, shareholders approved the 2025 Performance Incentive Plan, reserving 25 million shares, and the 2025 Stock Compensation Plan for Non-Employee Directors, reserving 1 million shares.

3.  Ms. Patterson's annual base salary will be $300,000, with additional compensation targets consistent with current salary band F targets (50% of base salary for annual incentives, $112,900 LTIP target, and $165,000 equity award target).
1. Ball Corporation completed a €850 million public offering of 4.250% Senior Notes due 2032 on May 19, 2025.
2.  The Notes are senior unsecured obligations of Ball Corporation, fully guaranteed by substantially all of its domestic subsidiaries.
3.  In a change of control repurchase event, Ball Corporation is required to offer to purchase the Notes at 101% of the principal amount plus accrued interest.

1. On May 18, 2025, Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) agreed to sell its ZT Group Int’l, Inc. subsidiary's data center infrastructure manufacturing business to Sanmina Corporation for $3.0 billion, including potential contingent consideration of up to $450 million.

2.  The transaction is expected to close near the end of 2025, contingent upon regulatory approvals and customary closing conditions;  if not completed by May 18, 2026 (with possible extensions), Sanmina will pay a termination fee of up to $153 million.
3. AMD will retain ZT Systems' design and customer enablement teams, and Sanmina will become a preferred manufacturing partner for AMD's cloud rack and cluster-scale AI solutions.
1. Discover Financial Services completed its merger with Capital One Financial Corporation on May 18, 2025, resulting in Discover ceasing to exist as a separate entity.
2.  Discover common stock was delisted from the NYSE on May 19, 2025, and Capital One intends to file for its deregistration.

3.  Gross-up agreements were approved on May 16, 2025, to reimburse certain Discover employees for excise taxes related to “excess parachute payments” under Section 4999 of the Internal Revenue Code, with a total cap of $25,000,000.
